awd_titl_txt: Workshops for Facilitating Faculty to Teach Electric Energy Courses for Combating Climate Change. To Be Held at The University of Minnesota.
awd_abstract_narration:
The global climate is changing rapidly and 97% of the climate scientists agree that it's changing because of human activities. The business as usual will result in catastrophic consequences with poorest of the poor at the frontline. Combating climate change in a serious way will necessitate that the emission of greenhouse gases be reduced to near-zero levels very soon, before the point of no return is reached.

This will require converting much of our energy use including transportation from fossil fuels to electricity generated from renewables such as solar and wind. Renewables are variable in nature and therefore an uninterruptible supply of electricity will require a "smart grid" with storage. Finally, this energy must be conserved and consumed very efficiently.  
To achieve this goal will entail a sea change in designing, manufacturing, delivering and consuming electricity.  Education is always the first step and a thorough look at the titles of the courses offered at the U.S. universities shows that only a handful of universities are offering appropriate courses.  Therefore, it is essential to quickly implement such courses at as many universities as possible.

With this challenge in mind, large numbers of forward-looking courses have been developed at the University of Minnesota through funding by the U.S. Navy, the Office of Naval Research (ONR).  These courses archive the institutional knowledge of academic and industrial experts from across the country, with the express purpose of being a resource for instructors at all universities and colleges to teach their own students teaching the teachers, as a force-multiplier. In addition, the content of all the course can be freely downloaded by anyone, thus making it accessible to practicing engineers as well.
 
Through this NSF grant, three faculty workshops will be held where the experts who developed these courses will familiarize the university instructors in-person who can then quickly implement these courses at their home institutions for the nationwide development of the workforce to combat climate change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Objectives:

              At the University of Minnesota through the funding from ONR, the content has been developed for large number of electric-energy courses that are essential in combating the crisis of changing climate. The objective of this project was to hold NSF-sponsored workshops with the express purpose of facilitating university faculty to teach these courses for the workforce development nationwide by graduating large number of students from their institutions to combat climate change.

              These workshops aimed to promote electric power engineering education and emphasize its significance in the broader context of societal needs, including national security and climate change. Efforts were concentrated on highlighting the importance of practical laboratory experiences, addressing the workforce attrition in power engineering, and inspiring young minds to recognize and engage with the role of Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) in sustainable solutions.

Major Activities:

Activities spanned a wide spectrum, from demonstrating developed laboratories in operation and disseminating course materials to brainstorming sessions with ECE department heads and faculty. These activities involved collaborative discussions, lightning talks, online courses, and hands-on sessions to address the various challenges and opportunities in the power engineering domain.

Organized a series of nine Workshops:

  1. Providing Hands-on Experience in Electric Power Engineering Education, Location: Online, Date: July 27, 2023
  2. Building a Robust Workforce in Electric Power Engineering, Location: Albuquerque, Date: March 16-17, 2023
  3. Crisis in Power Engineering Education ? A National Security Concern, Location: Minneapolis, Date: October 21-22, 2022
  4. Hardware Labs for Education & Research in Power, Power Electronics, Drives, Location: Online, Date: May 20, 2022
  5. ECE Dept Heads/Faculty Workshop-Disseminate Educational Material in Power, Location: Online, Date: March 8, 2021
  6. Teaching Electric Energy Courses to Rejuvenate Electric Power Curriculum, Location: Online, Date: August 7, 2020
  7. NSF-sponsored ECE Department Heads Online Workshop, Location: Online, Date: June 5, 2020
  8. NSF-sponsored Workshop courses, Location: Online, Date: July 10, 2019
  9. NSF-NAE-sponsored Workshop of ECE Department Heads ?Combating Climate Change: Can it also help the ECE Renaissance?", Location: Minneapolis, Date: April 19, 2019

Impact:

              These workshops were attended by over one-thousand participants. Their culmination is expected to lead to a holistic strategy that establishes a clear pathway from high schools to advanced degrees in power engineering. By providing accessible resources and fostering collaboration among stakeholders, the workshops aim to rejuvenate the power engineering workforce, bridge the educational gaps, and place emphasis on the pivotal role of ECE in addressing pressing global challenges such as climate change.
